tit.cmt: タイトルのため、括弧内の補足を削除しました。

sen.j: めんつゆとは出汁と醤油とみりん（または日本酒）、砂糖をベースに作られた調味料である。
sen.e: "Mentsuyu" is a Japanese liquid flavoring made mainly from soup stock, soy sauce, "mirin" (sweet "sake" [Japanese liquor] for cooking) - or sake itself - and sugar.
"Mentsuyu" is a Japanese flavoring sauce made mainly from soup stock, soy sauce, "mirin" (sweet "sake" [Japanese liquor] for cooking) - or sake itself - and sugar.
Mentsuyu is a Japanese flavoring sauce made mainly from soup stock, soy sauce, mirin (sweet sake [Japanese liquor] for cooking) - or sake itself - and sugar.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一し、文中のダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 主に素麺、蕎麦、うどん、ひやむぎなどの麺料理と一緒に食する。
sen.e: It is mainly served as the soup of noodles, such as "somen" (Japanese vermicelli), "soba" (Japanese noodles made from buckwheat), "udon" (Japanese noodles made from wheat), and "hiyamugi" (thin udon noodles served cold).

It is mainly served as soup with noodles, such as "somen" (Japanese vermicelli), "soba" (Japanese noodles made from buckwheat), "udon" (Japanese noodles made from wheat), and "hiyamugi" (thin udon noodles served cold).

It is mainly served as soup with noodles, such as somen (Japanese vermicelli), soba (Japanese noodles made from buckwheat), udon (Japanese noodles made from wheat), and hiyamugi (thin udon noodles served cold).
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一し、文中のダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 醤油を使ったかえしが登場する以前、うどんがすでに存在した室町時代にたれみそと呼ばれるものが存在した。
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, when "kaeshi" (the liquid flavoring served as the soba dipping soup, using soy sauce as its ingredient) did not exist yet (but udon already existed), there was a liquid flavoring called "taremiso."
sen.cmt: ・「かえし」については「そばつゆとして使われる調味料」と訳しています。（「醤油を使った」の部分も、「かえし」の解説の中に組み込んでいます。）
sen.e: In the Muromachi period, before "kaeshi" (the flavoring sauce served with soba for dipping, using soy sauce as an ingredient) existed, but after udon cam to exist, there was a flavoring sauce called "taremiso."

In the Muromachi period, before kaeshi (the flavoring sauce served with soba for dipping, using soy sauce as an ingredient) existed, but after udon came to exist, there was a flavoring sauce called taremiso.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一し、文中のダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。スペルを修正しました。

sen.j: そのたれみそはみそに水を加えて煮詰め、布袋入れて吊るし垂らして作っていたものである。
sen.e: The taremiso was made by adding water to soybean paste, boiling them down, and straining them with a cloth bag.
Taremiso was made by adding water to soybean paste, boiling it down, and straining it through a cloth bag.
Taremiso was made by adding water to soybean paste, boiling it down, and straining it through a cloth bag.

sen.j: 種類としてはたれみそをそのまま火を入れずに作る生たれと生たれに削った鰹節を入れて煮詰めて作る煮貫（にぬき）の2種類ある。
sen.e: Taremiso is categorized into two, "namatare" (the raw taremiso) and "ninuki" which is made by boiling down both namatare and shaved pieces of a dried bonito together.
Taremiso has two categories, "namatare" (the raw taremiso) and "ninuki" which is made by boiling down both namatare and shaved pieces of dried bonito together.
Taremiso has two categories, namatare (the raw taremiso) and ninuki which is made by boiling down both namatare and shaved pieces of dried bonito together.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一し、文中のダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: ちなみに生たれが省略され、たれとなった。
sen.e: Incidentally, "namatare" was abbreviated to "tare."
Incidentally, "namatare" was abbreviated to "tare."
Incidentally, namatare was abbreviated to "tare."
sen.cmt: 一部文中のダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: このことが生たれの名残と思われる。
sen.e: And today's "tare" seems to have originated from "namatare."
sen.cmt: ・原文の意味はよくわかりませんが、「こんにちの『たれ』はこの『生たれ』がもとになっていると思われる。」の意味と解して訳しています。
sen.e: And today's "tare" seems to have originated from "namatare."
And today's tare seems to have originated from namatare.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一し、文中のダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 寛永20年（1643年）以前に書かれた書物「料理物語」中にそばつゆに関して、うどんのたれみそもしくは煮貫に大根の汁を加え、鰹節・大根おろし・あさつきにからし・わさびを加えてもよいと書かれている。
sen.e: "Tail of Foods," a book written before 1643, says that soba dipping soup can be made by adding the juice of piquant "daikon" (Japanese radish) to taremiso (for udon) or to ninuki, and that one can add other ingredients to taste into the soup, that is, shaved pieces of a dried bonito, grated piquant daikon, chive, mustard, and Japanese horseradish.
sen.cmt: ・下記ホームページによれば、ここの「大根」は「辛味大根」のことです。[http://www.nichimen.or.jp/zatsugaku/46_02.html]
sen.e: "Tale of cooking," a book written before 1643, says that soba dipping sauce can be made by adding the juice of piquant "daikon" (Japanese radish) to taremiso (for udon) or to ninuki, and that one can add other ingredients to the sauce for flavor, such as, shaved pieces of dried bonito, grated piquant daikon, chive, mustard, and Japanese horseradish.

It says in 'Ryori Monogatari' (Tale of cooking), a book written before 1643, that soba dipping sauce can be made by adding the juice of piquant "daikon" (Japanese radish) to taremiso (for udon) or to ninuki, and that one can add other ingredients to the sauce for flavor, such as, shaved pieces of dried bonito, grated piquant daikon, chive, mustard, and Japanese horseradish.
sen.cmt: 書籍名のダブルクォーテーションをシングルクォーテーションに変更しました。

sen.j: なお寛延4年(1751年)の書物「蕎麦全書」には、つゆの製法が2種類存在していた。
sen.e: And "All About Soba," a book written in 1751, introduces two kinds of production method of soba dipping soup.
Also, "All About Soba," a book written in 1751, introduces two kinds of production methods for soba dipping sauce.
Also, 'Soba zensho' (All About Soba), a book written in 1751, introduces two kinds of production methods for soba dipping sauce.
sen.cmt: 書籍名のダブルクォーテーションをシングルクォーテーションに変更しました。

sen.j: たれみそを使ったつゆの作り方
sen.e: Production method of the soup that uses taremiso
How to make soup with taremiso.
How to make soup with taremiso
sen.cmt: ピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: たれみそ・酒・削った鰹節を合わせ煮詰める。
sen.e: You should boil down taremiso, sake, and shaved pieces of a dried bonito together.
You should boil down taremiso, sake, and shaved pieces of dried bonito together.
You should boil down taremiso, sake, and shaved pieces of dried bonito together.

sen.j: 煮詰めたものをこし、塩・たまり醤油で味を調える。
sen.e: You should strain them, and then add salt and thick soy sauce to taste.
You should strain them, and then add salt and thick soy sauce for flavor.
You should strain them, and then add salt and thick soy sauce for flavor.

sen.j: 上記のたれみそが当時、江戸の蕎麦屋で使われていたつゆで、そのままではなく温めて使用していた。
sen.e: The above-mentioned soup is what was really used at soba shops in Edo at that time, and it was used after being warmed up.
The above-mentioned soup, after being warmed, is what was really used at soba shops in Edo at that time.
The above-mentioned taremiso, after being warmed, is what was really used at soba shops in Edo at that time.

sen.j: しょうゆを使ったつゆの作り方
sen.e: Production method of the soup that uses soy sauce
How to make soup with soy sauce.
How to make soup with soy sauce
sen.cmt: ピリオドを削除しました。

sen.j: しょうゆ・酒・水を合わせ、弱火で煎じて作る。
sen.e: You should boil down soy sauce, sake and water together with low flame.
You should boil down soy sauce, sake and water together on a low flame.
You should boil down soy sauce, sake and water together on a low flame.

sen.j: 「蕎麦全書」の著者、日新舎友蕎子が自家製で作っていたものである。
sen.e: This is the soup that Yukyoshi NISSHINSHA, the writer of "ALL About Soba," used for her homemade soba.
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: This is the soup that Yukyoshi NISSHINSHA, the writer of "All About Soba," used for her homemade soba.
This is the soup that Yukyoshi NISSHINSHA, the writer of 'Soba zensho' used for his homemade soba.
sen.cmt: her →his としました。（日新舎友蕎子 は男性のようです）

sen.j: 本人は精進汁(動物性のタンパク質を使用しない汁)を好んでいたため鰹節を使わなかった。
sen.e: She herself did not use shaved pieces of a dried bonito, because she favored "Shojin-jiru" (the soup that does not include animal protein).
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: She herself did not use shaved pieces of dried bonito, because she favored "Shojin-jiru" (soup that does not include animal protein).
He himself did not use shaved pieces of dried bonito, because he favored Shojin-jiru (soup that does not include animal protein).
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一し、文中のダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: ただ、説明のつけだしにだしを好む人はかつおだしを加えるとよいと記述していた。
sen.e: However, she also wrote in her book that those who favored the animal protein could add the broth extracted from the bonito pieces to the above-mentioned soup.
sen.cmt: ・一原文一訳文の例外対処 ・原文の「説明のつけだしにだしを好む人は」の意味はよくわかりませんでした。 ここではとりあえず「上で説明したつゆに、動物性たんぱく質を好む人は、」の意味に解して訳しています。
sen.e: However, she also wrote in her book that those who favored the animal protein could add the broth extracted from the bonito pieces to the above-mentioned soup.
However, he also wrote in his book that those who favored the animal protein could add the broth extracted from the bonito pieces to the above-mentioned soup.
sen.cmt: her →his としました。（日新舎友蕎子 は男性のようです）

sen.j: それ以後、醤油とみりん（もしくは糖度の高い酒）を使用したつゆが普及する事になった。
sen.e: After that, the soup that used soy sauce and mirin (or sake of high sugar content, instead) as its ingredients became popular.
After that, the soup that used soy sauce and mirin (or sake with high sugar content) became popular.
After that, the soup that used soy sauce and mirin (or sake with high sugar content) became popular.

tit.j: 市販されているめんつゆ

sen.j: 主に、用途に応じて水で希釈して用いる（市販のめんつゆのほとんどは濃縮されている）。
sen.e: Mentsuyu today on the market is, in most cases, used after being diluted with water, because most of it is concentrated.
Mentsuyu today on the market is, in most cases, used after being diluted with water, because most of it is concentrated.
Mentsuyu today on the market is, in most cases, used after being diluted with water, because most of it is concentrated.

sen.j: 麺と一緒に食するという用途があるのはもちろんである。
sen.e: It is served as the soup of noodles, of course.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is, of course, served as soup with noodles.
It is, of course, served as soup with noodles.

sen.j: 煮物の味付けや鍋物の出汁として、あるいは天ぷらのつけ汁としても用いられる。
sen.e: It is also used as the flavoring for "nimono" (boiled foods), the soup stock for "nabemono" (foods cooked in a pot), or the dipping soup for "tenpura" (Japanese deep-fried dishes).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is also used as the flavoring for "nimono" (boiled foods), the soup stock for "nabemono" (foods cooked in a pot), or the dipping sauce for "tempura" (Japanese deep-fried dishes).
sen.cmt: reword. "Tempura" is commonly spelled with an "m" in English.
sen.e: It is also used as the flavoring for nimono (boiled foods), the soup stock for nabemono (foods cooked in a pot), or the dipping sauce for tempura (Japanese deep-fried dishes).
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一し、文中のダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 希釈せずにそのまま食材（冷奴や大根おろしなど）にかけて食べることもある。
sen.e: It is sometimes poured on foods, such as bean curd served cold and grated daikon, without being diluted.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is sometimes poured on foods, such as bean curd served cold and grated daikon, without being diluted.
It is sometimes poured on foods, such as bean curd served cold and grated daikon, without being diluted.

sen.j: 他の調味料と合わせてドレッシングや和風ソースなどに加工して用いることもある。
sen.e: Or, it is sometimes combined with other flavorings into a new dressing or a new sauce of a Japanese style.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Or, it is sometimes combined with other flavorings into a new dressing or a new Japanese style sauce.
Or, it is sometimes combined with other flavorings into a new dressing or a new Japanese style sauce.

sen.j: 他にも、卵かけご飯などを作る際の醤油の代わりに利用する、など用途は幅広い。
sen.e: Besides, it is used instead of soy sauce when "tamago kake gohan" (boiled rice topped or mixed with raw egg, and commonly, soy sauce is poured on it) is made, and there exist many other uses.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It can also be used, instead of soy sauce, with "tamago kake gohan" (boiled rice topped or mixed with raw egg, commonly with soy sauce poured on it), along with many other uses.
It can also be used, instead of soy sauce, with tamago kake gohan (boiled rice topped or mixed with raw egg, commonly with soy sauce poured on it), along with many other uses.
sen.cmt: 他の記事と統一し、文中のダブルクォーテーションを削除しました。

sen.j: 砂糖と醤油が用いられているため変質しやすく、開封後は冷暗所に保存し、なるべく早く使い切るのが望ましい。
sen.e: As it uses sugar and soy sauce as its ingredients, it easily deteriorates, so after opening it, one should keep it in a cool, dark place and use it up as soon as possible.
As it uses sugar and soy sauce as its main ingredients, it spoils easily, so after opening it, one should keep it in a cool, dark place and use it up as soon as possible.
As it uses sugar and soy sauce as its main ingredients, it spoils easily, so after opening it, one should keep it in a cool, dark place and use it up as soon as possible.

tit.e: About the soup stock used in mentsuyu
About the soup stock used in mentsuyu
About the soup stock used in mentsuyu

sen.j: 基本的にはみりん（または日本酒）のアルコールを飛ばしたものに砂糖と醤油を加え出汁で割って作る。
sen.e: Basically, mentsuyu is made by adding sugar, soy sauce, and soup stock to mirin (or sake) whose alcohol content is heated out.
Basically, mentsuyu is made by adding sugar, soy sauce, and soup stock to mirin (or sake) that has had its alcohol content reduced by heating.
Basically, mentsuyu is made by adding sugar, soy sauce, and soup stock to mirin (or sake) that has had its alcohol content reduced by heating.

sen.j: 出汁については、コンブ、鰹節、しいたけ、いりこなどを用いる。
sen.e: The soup stock is made from sea tangle, shaved pieces of a dried bonito, Lentinus edodes (a kind of mushroom), dried small sardines, and so on.
The soup stock is made from sea kelp, shaved pieces of dried bonito, shiitake mushroom (Lentinus edodes), dried small sardines, and so on.
sen.cmt: reword. I believe "Shiitake" is more commonly known than "Lentinus Edodes".
sen.e: The soup stock is made from sea kelp, shaved pieces of dried bonito, shiitake mushroom (Lentinus edodes), dried small sardines, and so on.

sen.j: 市販品は昆布と鰹節を用いたものが多い。
sen.e: The soup stock of mentsuyu on the market is mostly made from sea tangle and shaved pieces of a dried bonito.
The soup stock of mentsuyu on the market is mostly made from sea kelp and shaved pieces of dried bonito.
The soup stock of mentsuyu on the market is mostly made from sea kelp and shaved pieces of dried bonito.
